revision.comment: [[c:Help:Cat-a-lot|Cat-a-lot]]: Moving from [[Category:Landforms of North Central Province, Sri Lanka]] to [[Category:Bodies of water of Anuradhapura District]]
revision.text:
{{Infobox lake | name = Abhaya Wewa
{{lang|si|අභය වැව}} | image = Abhayavapi.jpg | alt = | caption = | image_bathymetry = | alt_bathymetry = | caption_bathymetry = | location = [[Anuradhapura]] | coords = {{coord|08|21|07.9|N|080|23|17.4|E|region:LK_type:waterbody|display=inline,title}} | type = [[Reservoir]] | inflow = | outflow = | catchment = | basin_countries = | agency = | date-built = 400 BC | date-flooded = | length = | width = | area = {{convert|1235|acre|ha sqmi|lk=off}} | depth = | max-depth = | volume = {{convert|133|e6cuft|e6m3|lk=off|abbr=on}} | residence_time = | shore = | elevation = | frozen = | islands = | cities = | reference = }} '''Abhayavapi''' ([[Sinhalese language|Sinhalese]]: {{lang|si|අභයවාපි}}) or commonly '''Abhaya Wewa''' ([[Sinhalese language|Sinhalese]]: {{lang|si|අභය වැව}}) is a [[reservoir]] built by King [[Pandukabhaya of Anuradhapura|Pandukabhaya]] who ruled in [[Anuradhapura Kingdom|Anuradhapura]] from 437 [[Before Christ|BC]] to 367 [[Before Christ|BC]], after constructing the city.{{cite web|title=Anuradhapura Sri Lanka|url=http://www.urlaub-sr-lanka.info/index.php/anuradhapura|publisher=Urlaub SriLanka|accessdate=2012-04-03}} This is now popularly known as ''Basawakkulama'' ([[Sinhalese language|Sinhalese]]: {{lang|si|බසවක්කුලම}}) tank which is not the original name. ==Size== Area is {{convert|1235|acre|ha sqmi|lk=off}}; length of the ''Waw Kandiya'' ([[Sinhalese language|Sinhalese]]: {{lang|si|වැව් කන්ඩිය}} [[English language|English]]: [[Embankment dam|embankment]]) is {{convert|5910|ft|mi}} and height is {{convert|22|ft|m}}. Width of the top of the embankment is {{convert|6|ft|m}} to {{convert|8|ft|m}}.{{cite web|title=King Pandukabhaya (437 BC – 367 BC)|url=http://mahavamsa.org/2008/05/king-pandukabhaya-437-bc-367-bc/|publisher=mahavamsa.org|accessdate=2012-04-03}}{{cite book |last=Brohier |first=R.L. |title=Seeing Ceylon|origyear=1965 |publisher=Sooriya Publishers, Colombo|year=2000 |pages=353–362|edition=4th}} ==Purpose== Built inside the [[Anuradhapura Kingdom|ancient Anuradhapura]], it supplied water to then city population. == See also == *''{{slink|Anuradhapura Kingdom|Irrigation and water management}}'' *''[[Irrigation works in ancient Sri Lanka]]'' *''[[Basawakkulama inscription]]'' ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:History of Sri Lanka|Irrigation works]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in North Central Province, Sri Lanka]] [[Category:Irrigation in Sri Lanka]] [[Category:Agronomy]] [[Category:Reservoirs in Sri Lanka]] [[Category:Bodies of water of Anuradhapura District]] {{SriLanka-geo-stub}} {{agri-stub}}

revision.comment: copy edit with [[Wikipedia:AutoWikiBrowser/General_fixes|General fixes]], replaced: l’s → l's
revision.text:
'''Advanced Metrics''' is the term for the empirical analysis of [[sports]], particularly [[statistics]] that measure in-game productivity and efficiency. Advanced metrics were first employed in baseball by [[Bill James]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://wwwdev.sabr.org/node/604/|title=Bill James Profile|first=Don|last=Zminda|work=Summer 2010 Baseball Research Journal.}}</ref> a pioneer in the field who is considered the father and public face of the practice.
==General principles== The basic principles of advanced metrics were outlined in ''The Sabermetric Manifesto'' by David Grabiner (1994).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://baseball1.com/baseball-archive/sabermetrics/sabermetric-manifesto/|title=The Sabermetric Manifesto|first=David J.|last=Grabiner|work=The Baseball Archive}}</ref> In the piece, Grabiner explains that Bill James defined sabermetrics, the first advanced metric, as the search for objective knowledge about sports.
To glean objective knowledge, advanced metrics practitioners gather and synthesize thousands of situational game data points from a wide variety of sources beyond high level box score information. A large volume of situational data is then distilled into sophisticated statistics that helps sports enthusiasts better understand, compare, and appreciate the on-field performances by athletes. Advanced metrics provide more objective answers to questions such as "which player on the [[Red Sox]] contributed the most to the team's offense?" or "who is the best wing player in the [[NBA]]?" or "how many touchdowns is [[Dez Bryant]] likely to score for the [[Dallas Cowboys|Cowboys]]?". By removing the subjective observations of sports media members and the emotional opinions of fans, advanced metrics offer a more clinical, rational prism from which to enjoy sporting events and consume sports media coverage.
==Early history== Advanced metrics were first posited in the mid-1900s, and [[Earnshaw Cook]] was one its earliest practitioners. Cook's research for his 1964 work, ''Percentage Baseball'' was the first publication siting advanced metrics to garner national media attention.<ref name="albert">{{cite book|last=Albert|first=James|author2=Jay M. Bennett |title=Curve Ball: Baseball, Statistics, and the Role of Chance in the Game|isbn=0-387-98816-5|year=2001|pages=170–171|publisher=[[Springer Science+Business Media|Springer]]}}</ref> Despite the competitive advantage offered by advanced metrics, the practice was unanimously dismissed by major sports organizations for most of the twentieth century.
In the late 1970s, Bill James helped bring SABR, which stands for the [[Society for American Baseball Research]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sabr.org/about|title=About SABR}}</ref> and the empirical analysis of athletic performance, to national prominence. The analytical perspective on sports championed by James and SABR developed a wider following after [[Sports Illustrated]] featured James in the article ''He Does It By The Numbers'' by Daniel Okrent (1981).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.si.com/vault/1981/05/25/825650/he-does-it-by-the-numbers-the-esoteric-equation-on-the-royals-scoreboard-in-kansas-city-is-only-one-of-the-far-out-findings-of-deep-thinking-baseball-statistician-bill-james|title=He Does It By The Numbers...|first=Daniel|last=Okrent|work=Sports Illustrated.}}</ref>
==Advanced metrics in baseball== Former [[Major League Baseball]] second baseman [[Davey Johnson]] was the first known member of a major sports organization to advocate for the use of advanced metrics. During his time with the [[Baltimore Orioles]], he used an [[IBM System/360]] to write a [[FORTRAN]] baseball [[computer simulation]] to determine the team's optimal starting lineup. When he proposed his findings to Orioles manager [[Earl Weaver]], Johnson's proposal was summarily dismissed. A decade later, after becoming the [[New York Mets']] manager in 1984, Johnson tasked a team employee with writing a [[dBASE II]] application to run sophisticated statistical models in order to better understand the capabilities and tendencies of the team's opponents.<ref name="porter19840529">{{cite news | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZqO7wRZjZQQC&lpg=PP1&dq=%22pc%20mag%22%20%22may%2029%201984%22&pg=PA210 | title=The PC Goes to Bat | work=PC Magazine | date=1984-05-29 | accessdate=24 October 2013 | author=Porter, Martin | pages=209}}</ref> At the close of the twentieth century, advanced metrics had gained significant acceptance by the management of many [[Major League Baseball]] clubs, notably the [[Oakland A's]], [[Boston Red Sox]] and [[Cleveland Indians]].
The adoption of advanced metrics by professional baseball franchises has been largely outpaced by sports fans and sports media. [[Bill James]]' first published his ''[[The Bill James Historical Baseball Abstract|Baseball Abstract]]'' in the early 1980s. In 1996, [[Baseball Prospectus]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.philbirnbaum.com/btn2000-05.pdf|title=Baseball Prospectus — Escaping Bill James' Shadow|first=James|last=Fraser|work=SABR Statistical Analysis Committee|pages=4–5|year=2000}}</ref> sought to build upon Bill James' work when it launched the website ''[http://www.BaseballProspectus.com BaseballProspectus.com]'' in order to present [[sabermetric]] research and related findings as well as publish advanced metrics such as [[EqA]], the [[Clay Davenport|Davenport Translations (DT's)]], and [[VORP]]. Today, Baseball Prospectus has grown into a multi-channel sports media organization employing a team of statisticians and writers who publish ''New York Times Best Selling'' books and host weekly radio shows and podcasts.
==Advanced metrics in basketball== [[University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill|North Carolina]], under coach [[Frank McGuire]], was the first known basketball organization to utilized advanced possession metrics to gain a competitive advantage. Since then, advanced metrics enthusiasts in basketball have borrowed aspects of Bill James' philosophy in order to create weighted statistics that measure each player and each team's on-court efficiency. Most basketball-specific advanced metrics feature a per-minute measurement to ensure that a player's incremental team contributions are measured irrespective of usage volume.
Beginning in the 1990s, statistician [[Dean Oliver (statistician)|Dean Oliver]] and [[ESPN]] sports writer [[John Hollinger]] first popularized the use of advanced metrics in basketball. Oliver's book ''Basketball On Paper''<ref>{{cite book|url=|title=Basketball On Paper|first=Dean|last=Oliver|work=Potomac Books|year=2003}}</ref> and Hollinger's ''Pro Basketball Forecast''<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/Pro-Basketball-Forecast-John-Hollinger/dp/1574889621|title=Pro Basketball Forecast|first=John|last=Hollinger|year=2005}}</ref> are credited with the advancement of basketball's version of sabermetrics, [[APBRmetrics]]. Major sports media proponents, such as Hollinger, have helped basketball evolve more quickly from rudimentary statistics to advanced metrics than some other major American sports.
[[Houston Rockets]]' [[Daryl Morey]] was the first [[NBA]] general manager to implement advanced metrics as a key aspect of player evaluation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.houstonpress.com/2007-11-01/news/rocket-science/|title=Rocket Science|first=Jason|last=Friedman|work=Houston Press|year=2007}}</ref> In the years that followed Morey's hiring, the [[NBA]] moved quickly to adopt advanced metrics-based player evaluation practices. In 2012, John Holliger left ESPN to become VP of Basketball Operations for the [[Memphis Grizzlies]].
Beyond professional basketball front offices, major sports media websites such as [http://www.basketballreference.com ''basketballreference.com''] and [http://www.hoopsdata.com ''hoopsdata.com''] are now dedicated to the collection, synthesis, and dissemination of advanced metrics to pro and college basketball organizations, sports media members, and fans.
==Advanced metrics in American football== The adoption of advanced metrics by college and professional football organizations has been a gradual evolution. While the sabermetrics revolution in baseball has already inspired a bestselling book, ''Moneyball'' by Michael Lewis, which also became a critically acclaimed film,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.oscars.org/awards/academyawards/84/nominees.html|title=84th Annual Academy Awards Nominees}}</ref> the advanced metrics movement in football has had no such prominence.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://newrepublic.com/article/112300/football-sabermetrics-how-stats-could-transform-nfl|title=4th Down? We're Going For It!|first=Nate|last=Cohn|work=New Republic|date=2013-02-01}}</ref>
In 2003, the advanced metrics-focused website [http://www.FootballOutsiders.com ''FootballOutsiders.com''] pioneered football's first comprehensive advanced metric, DVOA (defense-adjusted value over average),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.footballoutsiders.com/info/glossary|title=General Football Terms Glossary|work=Football Outsiders}}</ref> which compares a player's success on each play to the league average based on a number of variables including down, distance, location on field, current score gap, quarter, and strength of opponent. [[Football Outsiders]]' work has since been widely cited by analytical members the sports media establishment. A few years later, [[Pro Football Focus]] launched a comprehensive statistical database, which soon featured a sophisticated player grading system.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.profootballfocus.com/about/history/|title=History of ProFootballFocus}}</ref> [[Advanced Football Analytics]] (originally Advanced NFL Stats) has its EPA (expected points added) and WPA (win probability added) for NFL players.
[[Grantland]] lead football writer Bill Barnwell created the first advanced metrics focused on predicting the future performance of an individual player, the [[Speed Score]], which he referenced in a piece written for ''Pro Football Prospectus''. After analyzing data pertaining to running back success, Barnwell discovered that the most successful running backs at the [[NFL]] level were both fast and heavy, therefore, Speed Score weights 40-yard dash times by assigning a premium to bigger, often stronger, running backs.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.footballoutsiders.com/info/pro-football-prospectus|title=Pro Football Prospectus|first=Bill|last=Barnwell|work=Football Outsiders|year=2008}}</ref>
The fantasy football community has been one of the driving forces in the evolution of advanced metrics in American football. Fantasy sports writer, and author of ''How To Think Like A Fantasy Football Winner'', C.D. Carter is a leading advocate for the use of advanced metrics in fantasy football analysis. He and peers at [http://www.xnsports.com XN Sports], [http://www.NumberFire.com NumberFire], and the long-form fantasy football analysis site, [http://www.Rotoviz.com Rotoviz.com], have established an informal subculture of fantasy football sports writers who refer to themselves as "degens." The degen movement is responsible for the creation of numerous American football efficiency metrics that better explain past football performances and attempt to predict future player production. Height-adjusted Speed Score,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://moneyinthebananastand.com/2012/04/24/dominator-rating-height-adjusted-speed-score-and-wr-draft-rankings/|title=Dominator Rating, Height-adjusted Speed Score, and WR Draft Rankings|first=Shawn|last=Siegele|work=Money In The Banana Stand|year=2012}}</ref> College Dominator Rating,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://fantasydouche.com/2012/04/game-plan-now-available-in-paperback/|title=Game Plan|first=Frank|last=DuPont|year=2012}}</ref> Target Premium,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.xnsports.com/2014/02/04/fantasy-football-2013-wr-review-target-multiplier/|title=Fantasy Football 2013 WR Review|first=Rich|last=Hribar|work=XN Sports|year=2013}}</ref> Catch Radius,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://rotoviz.com/2014/03/the-catch-radius-project-in-search-of-better-td-production/|title=The Catch Radius Project: In Search of Better TD Production|first=Scott|last=Smith|work=RotoViz|year=2014}}</ref> Net Expected Points (NEP),<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.numberfire.com/info/glossary/|title=Glossary|work=NumberFire}}</ref> and Production Premium<ref name="Terms Glossary">{{cite web|url=http://www.playerprofiler.com/terms-glossary/|title=Terms Glossary|work=PlayerProfiler|year=2014}}</ref> were recently created and disseminated by degen writers and mathematicians. Building on the work of these writers, sites such as [http://www.PlayerProfiler.com PlayerProfiler.com] distill a wide variety of established advanced metrics into a single player snapshot designed to be palatable to the casual sports fan.<ref name="Terms Glossary"/>
==Examples== * [[Wins above replacement]] (WAR) * [[Value over replacement player]] (VORP) * [[Batting average on balls in play]] (BABIP) * [[Defense independent pitching statistics]] (DIPS) * [[Defense independent pitching statistics#FIP|Fielding independent pitching (FIP)]] * Fantasy batter value (FBV) * [[PITCHf/x]] * [[NERD (sabermetrics)|NERD]] * [[On-base plus slugging]] (OPS) * [[Range factor]] * [[Win shares]] * [[Player efficiency rating]] (PER) * Effective field-goal percentage (eFG%) * [[Pythagorean expectation]] * Net Expected Points * Production Premium * College Dominator Rating * Target Premium * Normalized Fantasy Points Per Game * [[Similarity score]] * [[Speed Score]] * Height-adjusted Speed Score * Burst Score * Agility Score * Catch Radius * Athleticism Score
==Notable proponents== * [[Sandy Alderson]]: Former [[general manager (baseball)|General Manager]] of the [[Oakland Athletics]], Alderson began focusing on sabermetric principles in the early 1990s toward obtaining relatively undervalued players.<ref name=Monebyall>{{cite book|last=Lewis|first=Michael M.|authorlink=Michael Lewis|title=[[Moneyball: The Art of Winning an Unfair Game]]|year=2003|publisher=[[W. W. Norton]]|location=[[New York City|New York]]|isbn=0-393-05765-8}}</ref> He became GM of the [[New York Mets]] in late 2010. * [[Billy Beane]]: Athletics' General Manager since 1997. Although not a public proponent of sabermetrics, it has been widely noted that Beane has steered the team during his tenure according to sabermetric principles.<ref>{{cite news|last=Kipen|first=D.|date=June 1, 2003|accessdate=November 2, 2007|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=/chronicle/archive/2003/06/01/RV145326.DTL|title=Billy Beane's brand-new ballgame|newspaper=[[San Francisco Chronicle]]}}</ref> In 2003, [[Michael Lewis (author)|Michael Lewis]] published ''[[Moneyball: The Art of Winning an Unfair Game|Moneyball]]'' about Billy Beane's use of a more quantitative approach. In 2011, [[Moneyball (film)|a film based on Lewis' book]] which dramatised Beane's use of sabermetrics was released, starring [[Brad Pitt]] in the role of Beane. * [[Earnshaw Cook]]: Early researcher and proponent of statistical baseball research. His 1964 book ''Percentage Baseball'' was the first book of baseball statistics studies to gain national media attention.<ref name="albert"/> * [[Paul DePodesta]]: A key figure in Michael Lewis' book ''[[Moneyball: The Art of Winning an Unfair Game]]'' as Beane's assistant in Oakland. * [[Theo Epstein]]: President of Baseball Operations for the [[Chicago Cubs]]. He was hired as GM of the Red Sox after owner John Henry hired sabermetrician [[Bill James]].<ref name="james">{{cite web|last=Neyer|first=Rob|date=November 5, 2002|accessdate=March 7, 2009|url=http://static.espn.go.com/mlb/s/2002/1105/1456563.html|title=Red Sox hire James in advisory capacity|work=[[ESPN.com]]}}</ref><ref>Shanahan, M. (May 23, 2005). Retrieved November 2, 2007 [http://www.boston.com/news/globe/living/articles/2005/06/23/his_numbers_are_in_the_ballpark/ His numbers are in the ballpark] ''[[The Boston Globe]]''</ref> * [[Bill James]]: Widely considered the father of sabermetrics due to his extensive series of books, although a number of less well known SABR researchers in the early 1970s provided a foundation for his work. He began publishing his ''Baseball Abstracts'' in 1977 to study some questions about baseball he found interesting,<ref>{{cite web|date=June 28, 2005|accessdate=November 2, 2007|url=https://www.pbs.org/thinktank/transcript1197.html|title=Bill James, Beyond Baseball|publisher=[[Public Broadcasting Service|PBS]]|work=[[Think Tank with Ben Wattenberg]]}}</ref> and their eclectic mix of essays based on new kinds of statistics soon became popular with a generation of thinking baseball fans.<ref>{{cite news|last=Ackman|first=D.|date=May 20, 2007|accessdate=November 2, 2007|url=http://www.opinionjournal.com/la/?id=110010232|title=Sultan of Stats|newspaper=[[The Wall Street Journal]]}}</ref> He discontinued the Abstracts after the 1988 edition, but continued to be active in the field. His two ''[[The Bill James Historical Baseball Abstract|Historical Baseball Abstract]]'' editions and ''[[Win shares|Win Shares]]'' book have continued to advance the field of sabermetrics, 25 years after he began. In 2002, James was hired as a special advisor to the [[Boston Red Sox]].<ref name="james"/> * [[Christina Kahrl]]: Co-founder of ''[[Baseball Prospectus]]'' and current [[ESPN]] columnist, Kahrl puts an emphasis on advanced baseball analytics. * [[Rob Neyer]]: Senior writer at ESPN.com and national baseball editor of [[SBNation]] and former assistant to [[Bill James]], he has worked to popularize sabermetrics since the mid-1980s. Neyer has authored or co-authored several books about baseball, and his journalistic writing focuses on sabermetric methods for looking at baseball players' and teams' performance.<ref>{{cite news|last=Jaffe|first=C.|date=October 22, 2007|accessdate=November 2, 2007|url=http://www.hardballtimes.com/main/article/rob-neyer-interview/|title=Rob Neyer Interview|work=[[The Hardball Times]]}}</ref> * [[Joe Posnanski]]: A popular baseball writer and a proponent of advanced metrics. * [[Dan LeBatard]]: A popular sports writer, radio and television host, and active proponent of advanced metrics. * [[Nate Silver]]: Writer and former managing partner of ''Baseball Prospectus'', inventor of [[PECOTA]]. Later applied sabermetric statistical models to the study of [[politics]], particularly elections, and published the results on his blog [[FiveThirtyEight]] (later affiliated with ''[[The New York Times]]'' and [[ESPN]]). * David Smith: Founded [[Retrosheet]] in 1989, with the objective of computerizing the [[box score]] of every major league baseball game ever played, in order to more accurately collect and compare the statistics of the game. * Keith Woolner: Creator of VORP, or Value over Replacement Player, is a former writer for sabermetric group/website ''Baseball Prospectus''. He was hired in 2007 by the [[Cleveland Indians]] as their Manager of Baseball Research & Analytics. * Voros McCracken: Developed a system called [[Defense Independent Pitching Statistics]] (DIPS) to evaluate a pitcher based purely on his ability. * C.D. Carter: Author of ''How To Think Like A Fantasy Football Winner'', Carter strongly advocates for the use of advanced metrics in fantasy football in his writing for the [[New York Times]] and several fantasy football-specific publications. * JJ Zachariason: Author of ''Late Round Quarterback'' and Editor-in-chief at [[NumberFire]], Zachariason utilizes a variety of advanced metrics in his writing about fantasy draft strategy. * Jonathan Bales: Author of ''Fantasy Football for Smart People'' spearheaded multiple in-depth quantitative studies that would become the philosophical underpinning of particular football advanced metrics. * Frank Dupont: Author of ''Game Plan'', Dupont created the College Dominator Rating metric, and soon after, launched [http://www.RotoViz.com RotoViz.com], a source of advanced metrics content for fantasy football enthusiasts. * Shawn Siegele: Creator of Height-adjusted Speed Score, Agility Score, and Breakout Age, Siegele is the foremost authority on the creation and application of advanced metrics in a fantasy football context. * Scott Smith: Creator of Catch Radius measurement and writer for Rotoviz and Player Profiler.
==Popular culture== * ''[[Moneyball (film)|Moneyball]]'', the 2011 film about [[Billy Beane]]'s use of sabermetrics to build the [[Oakland Athletics]]. The film is based on Michael Lewis' [[Moneyball|book of the same name]]. * The season 3 ''[[Numb3rs]]'' episode "Hardball" focuses on sabermetrics, and the season 1 episode "Sacrifice" also covers the subject.
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20080120185831/http://www.bepress.com/jqas/vol3/iss4/1/ "Using Box Scores to Analyze a Position's Value to Winning Games"] Academic research analyzing the impact of player contributions by position and by statistical category. *[http://baseballprospectus.com/ BaseballProspectus.com], publishes analytical articles as well as advanced statistics and projections for individuals and teams. *[http://www.hardballtimes.com/ Hardball Times.com], evaluates the preceding major league season and presents original research articles on various sabermetric topics. *[http://www.fangraphs.com FanGraphs.com], publishes advanced baseball statistics as well as graphics that evaluate and track the performance of players and teams. The site also features the analysis of play-by-play data and [[PITCHf/x]]. *[http://www.beyondtheboxscore.com/ BeyondTheBoxScore.com], specializes in advanced metrics analysis and research. It has also launched the careers of many successful sabermetricians. * [http://www.baseballthinkfactory.org/ BaseballThinkFactory.com], a web forum that includes extensive coverage of and commentary on baseball, usually from the perspective of sabermetrics. *[http://apbr.org/metrics/ APBR], a central discussion source for quantitative basketball analysis. *[http://www.82games.com 82games.com], offers a wealth of player and team data, +/-, counterpart, by position, time on clock. *[http://www.BasketballProspectus.com Basketball Prospectus.com], an on-based online basketball analysis site from the publishers of the Baseball Prospectus. *[https://www.basketball-reference.com BasketballReference.com], current and historical stats, including many advanced stats. *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070515005930/http://www.basketballvalue.com/ BasketballValue.com], features raw and adjusted plus-minus for players and lineup data. *[http://www.bballsports.com BBALLsports.com], site focusing on computer basketball simulations *[http://www.thecity2.com TheCity2.com], Golden State Warriors blog focusing on the advanced metrics enthusiast's perspective *[http://www.hoopdata.com HoopData.com], daily advanced box scores, advanced statistics, analysis and shot locations. *[http://www.kenpom.com KenPom.com], tracks [[College Basketball]] basic and advanced stats. *[https://web.archive.org/web/20051212064947/http://popcornmachine.net/GameFlows.html PopcornMachine.Net], documents game flow and charts player movement in and out of the game. *[http://espn.go.com/blog/statsinfo/ ESPN Stats & Info], makes advanced atatistics delivered to [[ESPN]] columnists and on-air talent available to the public. *[http://www.footballoutsiders.com FootballOutsiders.com], performs in-depth analysis of [[NFL]] play-by-play data to rate players and teams and publish counter-intuitive insights. *[http://www.profootballfocus.com ProFootballFocus.com], charts advanced [[NFL]] stats and features a sophisticated player grading system. *[http://www.rotoacademy.com/ RotoAcademy.com], helps fantasy football enthusiasts leverage advanced metrics to bridge the gap between the typical owner and fantasy football's elite. *[http://www.numberfire.com NumberFire.com], takes the unstructured, and often misleading, data and mines it for insight into future player and team performance. *[http://www.rotoviz.com RotoViz.com], provides data-intensive, often contrarian, fantasy football analysis as well as a suite of online player evaluation tools. *[http://www.xnsports.com/fantasy/fantasy-football/ XNSports.com], advanced metrics-focused fantasy football columns focusing player evaluation and fantasy draft strategy. *[http://www.playerprofiler.com, PlayerProfiler.com], distills a wide range of opportunity, productivity, and efficiency-related advanced metrics into a single player snapshot. *[http://www.zermattstats.com ZermattStats.com], advanced metrics and statistics for pro sports analysis.
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Sports science]] [[Category:Baseball statistics]] [[Category:Basketball statistics]] [[Category:Fantasy sports]]

revision.text:
{{For|the professor of pathology|Andrew O. M. Wilkie}} {{Use Australian English|date=January 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=December 2014}} {{Infobox politician | honorific-prefix = | name = Andrew Wilkie | honorific-suffix = [[Australian House of Representatives|MP]] | image = Andrew Wilkie 2.jpg | alt = | caption = Wilkie speaking at an anti-pulp mill rally in 2007 | constituency_MP = [[Division of Denison|Denison]] | parliament = Australian | majority = 15.6% | term_start = 21 August 2010 | term_end = | predecessor = [[Duncan Kerr]] | successor = | birth_name = Andrew Damien Wilkie | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1961|11|8}} | birth_place = [[Tamworth, New South Wales]], [[Australia]] | spouse = {{marriage|[[Simone Wilkie|Simone Burt]]
|1991|2003|reason={{abbr|div.|divorced}}}}
{{marriage|Kate Burton
|2004|2013|reason={{abbr|div.|divorced}}}} | children = 2 | alma_mater = [[Royal Military College, Duntroon]]
[[University of New South Wales]] | party = [[Independent (politician)|Independent]] (2008–present) | otherparty = [[Liberal Party of Australia|Liberal]] (1980–1986)
[[Australian Greens|Greens]] (2003–2008) | residence = [[Hobart]], [[Tasmania]], [[Australia]] | occupation = [[Infantry officer]]
([[Australian Army]]) | profession = [[Soldier]]
[[Politician]] | website = {{URL|http://www.andrewwilkie.org}} | allegiance = [[Australia|Commonwealth of Australia]] | branch = [[Australian Army]] | serviceyears = 1980–2004 | rank = [[Lieutenant Colonel]] | unit = [[Royal Australian Infantry Corps]] | commands = [[6th Battalion, Royal Australian Regiment]] | battles = | awards = }} [[File:Andrew Wilkie Greens 2007 launch.jpg|thumb|Andrew Wilkie ran for the Australian Greens in 2007]] '''Andrew Damien Wilkie''' (born 8 November 1961 in [[Tamworth, New South Wales|Tamworth]], New South Wales, Australia) is an Australian politician and independent federal member for [[Division of Denison|Denison]]. Before entering politics Wilkie was an infantry officer in the [[Australian Army]].[https://www.aph.gov.au/Senators_and_Members/Parliamentarian?MPID=C2T Mr Andrew Wilkie MP], Australian Parliament House Biographies; 19 August 2017 Wilkie served with the Australian Army from 1980 to 2004. An officer with the [[Royal Australian Infantry Corps]] who had earlier commanded a company of the [[6th Battalion, Royal Australian Regiment]],[https://www.greenleft.org.au/content/independent-mp-andrew-wilkie-bring-our-troops-home-afghanistan: Independent MP Andrew Wilkie - Bring our troops home from Afghanistan]; 19 August 2017 at the time of his entry to public life Wilkie was posted to Australia's [[Office of National Assessments]] as an [[Intelligence analysis|intelligence analyst]]. In 2003, in the lead-up to the [[Iraq War]], he resigned from his position at ONA because he feared the humanitarian consequences of invasion, such as [[Saddam Hussein]] using his weapons of mass destruction or assisting terrorists. Following his resignation he said: Iraq's "weapons of mass destruction program is very disjointed and contained by the regime that's been in place since the last Gulf War. And there is no hard intelligence linking the Iraqi regime to al-Qaeda in any substantial or worrisome way." He opposed [[Australian contribution to the 2003 invasion of Iraq|Australia's contribution]] to the [[2003 invasion of Iraq]] under the [[Howard government]].[http://www.abc.net.au/am/content/s804540.htm Senior intelligence officer, Andrew Wilkie, resigns in protest]; ABC Radio; AM Program; 12 March 2003.{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/pm/content/2004/s1037355.htm |title=PM – Andrew Wilkie discusses WMD doubts |publisher=Abc.net.au |date= |accessdate=2014-06-12}} Wilkie later argued the Iraq War was based on a "lie".[http://www.abc.net.au/news/2016-07-07/wilkie-blames-bali-bombing-lindt-siege-on-iraq-war-involvement/7576480 Chilcot report: Andrew Wilkie blames Bali bombing, Lindt Cafe siege on Australia's Iraq War involvement]; ABC News; 7 July 2016 Wilkie has been active in politics since 2003. He was a [[Australian Greens|Greens]] candidate for the federal [[Division of Bennelong]] in the [[Australian federal election, 2004|2004 federal election]] and for the [[Australian Senate|Senate]] in Tasmania at the [[Australian federal election, 2007|2007 federal election]]. In 2010 he stood as an independent candidate for the state seat of [[Division of Denison (state)|Denison]] at the [[Tasmanian state election, 2010|Tasmanian state election]], narrowly missing out on the final vacancy. Later in the year, again as an independent candidate, he ran for the [[Division of Denison|federal seat of Denison]] at the [[Australian federal election, 2010|2010 federal election]] and won, finishing third on the primary vote but winning the seat after the distribution of preferences.{{cite web |url=http://vtr.aec.gov.au/HouseDivisionFirstPrefs-15508-194.htm |work=Election 2010 Virtual Tally Room: The official election results |title=TAS DIVISION – DENISON |publisher=Australian Electoral Commission |year=2010 |accessdate=27 August 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100827165541/http://vtr.aec.gov.au/HouseDivisionFirstPrefs-15508-194.htm |archivedate=27 August 2010 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }} Wilkie finished first on the primary vote at the [[Australian federal election, 2013|2013 federal election]] and increased his margin. ==Early life and education== Wilkie trained at the [[Royal Military College, Duntroon]]Wilkie, 2004 p. 2 and graduated in 1984. He joined the [[Young Liberals (Australia)|Young Liberals]] while a cadet. He also studied at the [[University of New South Wales]], and holds a [[Bachelor of Arts]] degree, a Graduate Diploma of Management, and a Graduate Diploma of Defence Studies. After graduation and being stationed in Brisbane, he joined the [[Liberal Party of Australia|Liberal Party]] before allowing his membership to lapse.{{cite news |url=http://www.smh.com.au/articles/2003/12/09/1070732214670.html |title=Former spy eyes greener pastures |work=The Sydney Morning Herald |date=10 December 2003}} His military career spanned 1980–2001 and he rose to the rank of [[lieutenant colonel]].Wilkie, 2004, back cover He was seconded to the ONA, an Australian [[intelligence agency]], from 1999 until late 2000. After a stint with US defence company [[Raytheon]], Wilkie returned to the ONA shortly after the [[September 11 attacks|11 September attacks]]. ==Military career, 1980—2003== Wilkie joined the Army in 1980, and was first stationed in [[Brisbane, Queensland]]. He served in the [[Royal Australian Infantry Corps]] and achieved the rank of [[Lieutenant Colonel]]. He was discharged in 2001. ===Opposition of Iraq War, and aftermath (2001–2003)=== In the aftermath of the September 11 Terror Attacks, the United States called upon Australia to assist in enforcing the 1991 Gulf War peace treaty which had been [[Iraq and weapons of mass destruction|repeatedly breached by Saddam Hussein's Iraq]]. Iraq failed to comply with demands to allow unfettered arms inspections, and the [[Howard Government]] elected to send forces to support the 2003 US invasion of Iraq. While the Government was considering the case for war, Wilkie was asked to report on humanitarian considerations. According to a leaked report published in the ''[[Herald Sun]]'', in December 2002 Wilkie had submitted an ONA report on the humanitarian implications of war in Iraq to the Government. In it he cautioned against unpredictable but potentially serious humanitarian consequences of war against Saddam, such as the use of weapons of mass destruction against civilians.[http://blogs.news.com.au/heraldsun/andrewbolt/index.php/heraldsun/comments/not_just_a_leak_but_a_lie/P20/ Not just a leak but a lie]; ''Herald Sun''; 13 November 2008 In response to [[popular opposition to war on Iraq|widespread opposition to the war]], Wilkie gave extensive television interviews and accepted numerous offers of public speaking engagements.{{Citation needed|date=August 2010}} He subsequently gave evidence to official British and Australian inquiries into the government's case for involvement in the Iraq war.{{cite web |url=http://www.aph.gov.au/hansard/joint/commttee/j6782.pdf |title=Intelligence on Iraq's weapons of mass destruction |publisher=Official Committee Hansard, Commonwealth of Australia |date=22 August 2003}} In 2004, Wilkie published ''Axis of Deceit'', an account of the reasons for his decision and its results.Wilkie, 2004 He describes his views on the nature of intelligence agencies and the analyst's work, the history of the Iraq war, the untruths of politicians and the attempts to suppress the truth.{{Citation needed|date=August 2010}} Following Britain's 2016 [[Chilcot Report]] which criticised the Blair Government's prosecution of the war, Wilkie attributed all terror attacks against Australians since the Iraq invasion to the nation's involvement in the Iraq War. Wilkie said that Howard, Bush and Blair should be brought before an international court, and called for Australia to hold another inquiry into the war. Howard rejected Wilkie's proposition and called him "irrational", telling the media: "Andrew Wilkie said the Iraq invasion was responsible for the Bali attack of 2005. What about the Bali attack of 2002? And he blamed it [the Iraq War] on the Lindt Cafe siege. I mean, this is irrational."[http://www.abc.net.au/news/2016-07-07/chilcot-inquiry-john-howard-responds/7577306 Chilcot report: John Howard defends decision to send Australian troops to Iraq]; ABC News online, 7 July 2016. ===Resignation from ONA (2003)=== On 11 March 2003, Wilkie resigned from the ONA, asserting that while Iraq likely did possess weapons of mass destruction, its program in this area was contained, that international sanctions were having an effect, and therefore an invasion was premature and also reckless in potentially provoking Saddam Hussein to use those weapons and possibly even begin supporting terrorism.{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/lateline/content/2003/s804475.htm |title=Lateline – 11/03/2003: Senior intelligence officer resigns over Iraq . Australian Broadcasting Corp |publisher=Abc.net.au |date= |accessdate=2014-06-12}} He told the ABC: "I think that invading Iraq at this time would be wrong. For a start, Iraq does not pose a security threat to any other country at this point in time. Its military is very weak, it's a fraction of the size of the military at the time of the invasion of Kuwait. Its weapons of mass destruction program is very disjointed and contained by the regime that's been in place since the last Gulf War. And there is no hard intelligence linking the Iraqi regime to al-Qaeda in any substantial or worrisome way."[http://www.abc.net.au/am/content/s804540.htm Senior intelligence officer, Andrew Wilkie, resigns in protest]; ABC Radio, AM Program; 12 March 2003 Wilkie later told the press that in the lead up to his resignation he had increasingly encountered [[ethical dilemma|ethical conflict]] between his duty as an intelligence officer and his "respect for the truth".{{cite web |url=http://www.pressclubonline.com/Assets/33/1/AndrewWilkieSpeech.pdf |format=PDF |title=Club Lunch – Speaker Andrew Wilkie |publisher=Melbourne Press Club |date= 31 July 2003}} During his later political career, Wilkie said that the notion that Iraq had weapons of mass destruction and co-operated with terrorists had been "a lie" and denounced other politicians who had made the claim.[http://www.abc.net.au/news/2016-07-07/wilkie-blames-bali-bombing-lindt-siege-on-iraq-war-involvement/7576480 Chilcot report: Andrew Wilkie blames Bali bombing, Lindt Cafe siege on Australia's Iraq War involvement]; ABC News online, 7 July 2016. ==Political career, 2004—present== ===Candidacy for Australian Greens (2004–2008)=== Wilkie was a member of the [[Australian Greens]] by 2004 and stood unsuccessfully on the Tasmanian Senate ticket in 2007. He resigned from the party in 2008, criticising it for a lack of professionalism.{{cite news |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2010/08/26/2994143.htm |title=Who is Andrew Wilkie? |first=Conor |last=Duffy |work=ABC News Online |publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation |date=26 August 2010 |accessdate=29 August 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100829044014/http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2010/08/26/2994143.htm| archivedate= 29 August 2010 | deadurl= no}} Wilkie stood as the [[Australian Greens]] [[2004 Australian Greens candidates|candidate]] for [[Division of Bennelong|Bennelong]] against [[John Howard]] in the [[Australian House of Representatives]] in the [[Australian federal election, 2004|2004 federal election]]. He was a supporter of the [['Not happy John!' campaign]] which ran during the election campaign.{{cite news |first=Phillip |last=Hudson |url=http://www.theage.com.au/articles/2004/10/09/1097261864643.html |title=Four in a row for Coalition |work=The Age |date=10 October 2004 |location=Canberra, Australia |accessdate=29 August 2010 }} Polling 16 per cent of the primary vote, Wilkie achieved the fifth-highest Green vote percentage across the nation. This result was a considerable increase from the Greens' [[Australian federal election, 2001|previous (2001) election]] figure of 5%. Although Wilkie's vote was nowhere near enough to win the seat, there was a swing of 3.18% against John Howard, the sitting Liberal Party member and prime minister, who achieved a primary vote of 49.89%, which resulted in the seat being decided on preferences.{{cite web |url=http://results.aec.gov.au/12246/results/HouseDivisionFirstPrefs-12246-105.htm |title=House of Representatives Division First Preferences |publisher=[[Australian Electoral Commission]] |date=9 November 2005 |work=Virtual Tally Room |accessdate=29 August 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100813092913/http://results.aec.gov.au/12246/results/HouseDivisionFirstPrefs-12246-105.htm| archivedate= 13 August 2010 | deadurl= no}} The seat reverted to a margin of 5% in [[Australian federal election, 2007|2007]], but Green votes were amongst the preferences that saw Labor's [[Maxine McKew]] defeat Howard. He was nominated as the Greens' second Tasmanian candidate for the [[Australian Senate]] at the [[Australian federal election, 2007|2007 federal election]], behind the Greens federal leader, [[Bob Brown]].{{cite news |url=http://www.theage.com.au/news/National/Greens-announce-Tasmanian-Senate-ticket/2007/02/16/1171405424983.html |title=Greens announce Tasmanian Senate ticket |work=The Age |location=Australia |date=16 February 2007 |accessdate=29 August 2010}} ===Member of Parliament (2010–present)=== ; Gillard-Rudd Government Wilkie stood as an independent candidate in the state [[Division of Denison (state)|Division of Denison]], based around central Hobart, in the [[Tasmanian state election, 2010|2010 Tasmanian state election]].{{cite news |first=Sue |last=Neales |url=http://www.themercury.com.au/article/2009/03/20/62275_tasmania-news.html |title=Wilkie's Denison punt |work=The Mercury |date=20 March 2009}} He won 8.44 per cent of first preference votes,[http://www.electoral.tas.gov.au/pages/HouseOfAssembly/HoA2010/Results/Denison/DenisonFirst.html Division of Denison – first preference figures], ''Tasmanian Electoral Commission'' and was beaten by 315 votes by Liberal candidate [[Elise Archer]] after distribution of preferences.{{cite web|url=http://www.electoral.tas.gov.au/pages/HouseOfAssembly/HoA2010/Results/Denison/DenisonDist.html |title=Tasmanian Electoral Commission |publisher=Electoral.tas.gov.au |date=8 April 2010 |accessdate=2014-06-12}} Wilkie stood as an independent for the federal Division of Denison, which has the same boundaries as the state division, in the [[Australian federal election, 2010|2010 federal election]]{{cite web |url=http://www.aec.gov.au/election/tas/denison.htm |title=Voting in the electorate of Denison (tas), 2010 federal election |publisher=[[Australian Electoral Commission]] |date=10 August 2010}} and won more than 20 per cent of the primary vote. The [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]] declared Wilkie the winner on election night, predicting that Wilkie would be vaulted into second place on Green preferences and ultimately take the seat on Liberal preferences.{{cite web |url=http://blogs.abc.net.au/antonygreen/2010/08/distributing-preferences-in-denison.html |first=Antony |last=Green |authorlink=Antony Green |title=Distributing Preferences in Denison |date=24 August 2010 |publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation |accessdate=25 August 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100825023708/http://blogs.abc.net.au/antonygreen/2010/08/distributing-preferences-in-denison.html| archivedate= 25 August 2010 | deadurl= no}} On the third count, he picked up enough Green preferences to put him in second place, ahead of the Liberal candidate. On the fourth count, more than 79 percent of the Liberal candidate's preferences flowed to Wilkie, allowing him to win the seat with just over 51 per cent of the two-candidate-preferred vote. Reportedly, Wilkie benefited from a lacklustre campaign by Labor's candidate, Jonathan Jackson, the son of former longtime state Labor minister [[Judy Jackson]]; Labor lost almost a quarter of its primary vote from 2007, and Labor theoretically tallied a [[two-party-preferred vote|two-party vote]] of more than 65 percent.{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/federal-election-2013/guide/deni/ |title=Denison – Australia Votes | Federal Election 2013 (Australian Broadcasting Corporation) |publisher=Abc.net.au |date= |accessdate=2014-06-12}} Following the election, he declared that he would back the [[Australian Labor Party]] minority government, in return for the [[Julia Gillard|Gillard]] government committing $340 million to the [[Royal Hobart Hospital]] and a commitment to reduce problem gambling. In contrast the Coalition offered A$1 billion in funding for the same hospital in their offer to Wilkie, which was perceived by Wilkie as "almost reckless".{{cite web|author=Tim Leslie |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2010/09/03/3001227.htm |title=Abbott's 'reckless' offer pushed Wilkie to Labor |publisher=ABC |location=Australia |date=3 September 2010 |accessdate=19 November 2011}} Wilkie described this as being part of the evidence that Labor would better be able to offer a more stable, competent and ethical government than the Coalition. The agreement to support the government only extended to issues of supply and [[no confidence]] motions.{{cite news |first=Emma |last=Rodgers |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2010/09/02/3000874.htm |title=Wilkie backs Gillard government |work=ABC News |date=2 September 2010}} Wilkie was unexpectedly admitted to hospital on 12 November 2010 to have his [[gall bladder]] removed.{{cite news|url=http://www.adelaidenow.com.au/news/breaking-news/wilkie-in-hospital-for-gall-bladder-operation/story-e6frea73-1225952595502 |title=Wilkie in hospital for gall bladder operation |agency=AAP |publisher=Adelaidenow.com.au |date=12 November 2010 |accessdate=19 November 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/news/breaking-news/wilkie-recovering-from-surgery/story-e6frf7kf-1225952808622 |title=Wilkie recovering from surgery |work=Herald Sun |date=12 November 2010 |accessdate=19 November 2011}} This did not interfere with his ability to attend Parliamentary sittings and he was present at the debate on same-sex marriage on 15 November, where he seconded the motion raised by Greens member [[Adam Bandt]].{{cite web|url=http://australianpolitics.com/2010/11/15/house-of-representatives-debates-gay-marriage-resolution.html |title=House of Representatives debates gay marriage |publisher=Australianpolitics.com |date=15 November 2010 |accessdate=19 November 2011}} In April 2011 during push for gambling reform initiated by Wilkie, [[News Limited]] media reported allegations by a former Duntroon army cadet that in 1983 Wilkie had forced junior cadets to salute to [[Adolf Hitler]] on the 50th anniversary of the latter's rise to power.{{Cite news |url=http://www.abc.net.au/worldtoday/content/2011/s3192529.htm |title=Wilkie admits bastardising Duntroon cadets |date=15 April 2011 |accessdate=15 April 2011 }} In response, Wilkie said he had been "involved in bastardisation of teenage army cadets" at Duntroon during the 1980s and apologised for this "inappropriate behaviour" but could not recall the specific incident alleged.{{Cite news |url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/news/andrew-wilkie-caught-up-in-nazi-salute-allegation/story-e6frf7jo-1226039348399 |title=Andrew Wilkie caught up in Nazi salute allegation |first=Andrew |last=Rule |date=15 April 2011 |accessdate=15 April 2011}} With regard to the allegation and its publication, he accused pro-[[Poker machine|Pokies]] advocates of running a smear campaign against him. On 21 January 2012 Wilkie announced that he was withdrawing his support for the Labor government after it broke the agreement he had signed with Julia Gillard to implement mandatory pre-commitment for all poker machines by 2014. He stated that he would support the government's alternative plan to trial pre-commitment in the ACT and require that pre-commitment technology be installed in all poker machines built from 2013, but that this fell short of what he had been promised in return for supporting the government.{{cite news|title=Wilkie withdraws support over broken pokies deal|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2012-01-21/wilkie-withdraws-support-over-broken-pokies-deal/3786040|accessdate=21 January 2012|newspaper=ABC News|date=21 January 2012}} Gillard and [[Minister for Families, Housing, Community Services and Indigenous Affairs (Australia)|Minister for Families, Housing, Community Services and Indigenous Affairs]] [[Jenny Macklin]] argued that there was not enough support in the House of Representatives for Wilkie's preferred option for it to be passed, and that they had been advised it was technically infeasible to implement mandatory commitment within the time frame he had specified.{{cite news|last=Peatling|first=Stephanie|title=PM unveils compromise deal over pokies reform|url=http://www.smh.com.au/national/pm-unveils-compromise-deal-over-pokies-reform-20120121-1qb1m.html|accessdate=21 January 2012|newspaper=The Sydney Morning Herald|date=21 January 2012}} In making his announcement, Wilkie stated that he would only support motions of no confidence against the government "in the event of serious misconduct" and would "consider budget measures on their merits". ; Abbott-Turnbull Government Wilkie was reelected in the [[Australian federal election, 2013|2013 federal election]], gaining a swing of 15 points to increase his majority to 65 percent. In October 2014, Wilkie wrote to the [[International Criminal Court]], seeking to prosecute Prime Minister [[Tony Abbott]] and the 19 members of his cabinet for crimes against humanity, with particular concerns relating to the treatment of asylum seekers.{{cite web|url=http://www.news.com.au/national/andrew-wilkie-seeks-to-prosecute-abbott-government-over-inhumane-treatment-of-asylum-seekers/story-fncynjr2-1227098266151 |title=Andrew Wilkie seeks to prosecute Abbott Government over 'inhumane' treatment of asylum seekers |publisher=News.com.au |date=2014-10-22 |accessdate=2018-06-26}} ==Political views== Wilkie made the removal of [[poker machine]]s his primary campaign issue in the 2010 Tasmanian state election. He strongly opposed to the [[Bell Bay Pulp Mill|Gunns pulp mill]] in the Tamar Valley. Wilkie is a supporter of [[voluntary euthanasia]], provided that there are safeguards in place, he is also in favour of [[same-sex marriage]] and access to abortion. He supported a [[National Broadband Network]] and opposed the Howard Government's [[WorkChoices]] industrial relations reforms.{{cite web |title=Andrew Wilkie – Independent Candidate for Denison |url=http://www.andrewwilkie.org/content/index.php/site/issues |accessdate=29 August 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100824193012/http://www.andrewwilkie.org/content/index.php/site/issues |archivedate=24 August 2010 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }} During Wilkie's maiden speech to federal parliament on 30 September 2010, he called for withdrawal of Australian troops from [[Afghanistan]]. He said Australia should be more willing to say "no" more often to the United States. He said that there could be no hope for peace in Afghanistan until foreign troops are withdrawn: "No-one should be fooled by the Australian Government's periodic efforts to tinker around the edges with Australia's commitment to Afghanistan" and that "The reality is that the best plan the Australian Government can come up with so far is simply to continue to support whatever the US Government comes up with and that alone is no plan—it's just reinforcing failure." Wilkie's comments came amid opposition calls for more support for Australia's troops in Afghanistan. During his speech Wilkie also canvassed his push for legislation to protect [[whistleblower]]s, measures to tackle problem gambling and a more humane approach to asylum seekers.{{cite web |title=Wilkie takes stand against Afghan war |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2010/09/30/3025977.htm |accessdate=1 October 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101003151043/http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2010/09/30/3025977.htm| archivedate= 3 October 2010 | deadurl= no}} In March 2011 he called Liberal MPs [[Cory Bernardi]] and [[Scott Morrison]] "a disgrace to high office" calling on [[Tony Abbott]] to sack them both and referring to endemic racism in the Liberal party.{{cite news|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/national-affairs/independent-andrew-wilkie-calls-on-abbott-to-lance-the-boil-of-racism-in-his-party/story-fn59niix-1226014258266|title=Independent Andrew Wilkie calls on Abbott to 'lance the boil' of racism in his party|last=Kelly|first=Joe|date=1 March 2011|work=The Australian|accessdate=2 March 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110306051149/http://www.theaustralian.com.au/national-affairs/independent-andrew-wilkie-calls-on-abbott-to-lance-the-boil-of-racism-in-his-party/story-fn59niix-1226014258266| archivedate= 6 March 2011 | deadurl= no}} ===Pokies and pre-commitment=== Wilkie campaigned heavily against [[poker machine]]s (colloquially "pokies") at the [[Australian federal election, 2010|2010 federal election]] and immediately began forging ties with independent anti-pokies Senator [[Nick Xenophon]].{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/worldtoday/content/2010/s2994058.htm |title=Wilkie, Xenophon team up against pokies: ABC The World Today 26 August 2010 |publisher=ABC |location=Australia |date=2 October 1980 |accessdate=19 November 2011}} Wilkie claimed that problem gamblers in Australia lose $5 billion each year on pokies.{{cite web|url=http://www.andrewwilkie.org/content/index.php/aw/issues_policy_extended/C18 |title=Poker Machines |publisher=AndrewWilkie.org |accessdate=19 November 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111117020825/http://www.andrewwilkie.org/content/index.php/aw/issues_policy_extended/C18 |archivedate=17 November 2011 |df=dmy }} The Labor government gave two commitments regarding pokies in exchange for Wilkie's support. The first was mandatory "pre-commitment" technology, which required a better to commit how much they were willing to bet before starting.{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/4corners/content/2011/s3245356.htm |title=Wilkie's Gamble: ABC Four Corners 20 June 2011 |publisher=ABC |location=Australia |date=20 June 2011 |accessdate=19 November 2011}} The second commitment was to introduce $1 maximum bet per spin machines that would not require pre-commitment. Wilkie argued these $1 maximum machines would be safer.{{cite web|author=Cowboy |url=http://www.international.to/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=2215:andrew-wilkie-complains-about-opposition-to-his-poker-machine-plans&catid=80:politics&Itemid=120 |title=Andrew Wilkie complains about opposition to his poker machine plans: The International 1 September 2011 |publisher=International.to |date=4 September 2011 |accessdate=19 November 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120328055328/http://www.international.to/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=2215%3Aandrew-wilkie-complains-about-opposition-to-his-poker-machine-plans&catid=80%3Apolitics&Itemid=120 |archivedate=28 March 2012 |df=dmy }} The [[Tony Abbott|Abbott]] [[Coalition (Australia)|Coalition]] opposed the plans, with Abbott saying "it is not [[Liberal Party of Australia|Liberal Party]] policy" and it will be "expensive and ineffective". According to polling, Wilkie's proposals were supported by a clear majority of voters across the spectrum.{{cite web|url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/news/more-news/liberal-voters-like-pokies-laws/story-fn7x8me2-1226163393107 |title=Liberal voters support pokies crackdown: |work=Herald Sun |location=Australia |date=11 October 2011 |accessdate=19 November 2011}} Wilkie and Xenophon argued that "$12 billion a year is lost on the pokies. 100,000 Australians are problem gamblers and an additional 200,000 are significantly at risk of developing a full-blown addiction", and that the legislation is necessary to "[help] those who sometimes lose up to $1200 an hour on the pokies."{{cite web |url=http://www.nickxenophon.com.au/itsabigfatlie/ |accessdate=3 October 2011 | title=Its a Big Fat Lie}} The Labor government withdrew their support for Wilkies's plan when their strength in parliament improved through a change of Speaker.{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2012-01-21/wilkie-withdraws-support-over-broken-pokies-deal/3786040 |title=Wilkie withdraws support over broken pokies deal – ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation) |publisher=Abc.net.au |date= |accessdate=2014-06-12}} The plan came under sustained attack from clubs, hotels and other businesses which financially benefit from pokies.{{cite web|url=http://news.ninemsn.com.au/article.aspx?id=8351969 |title=Wilkie is fearless on pokies says Xenophon: NineMSN 26 September 2011 |publisher=News.ninemsn.com.au |accessdate=19 November 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121007030552/http://news.ninemsn.com.au/article.aspx?id=8351969 |archivedate=7 October 2012 |df=dmy }} Xenophon responded by accusing them of misrepresenting plans and creating hype around the issue.{{cite web|last=Editor |first=State |url=http://www.adelaidenow.com.au/mr-x-hits-back-at-pokies-lies/story-e6frea6u-1226146042200 |title=Mr X hits back at pokies 'lies': |work=AdelaideNow |date=26 September 2011 |accessdate=19 November 2011}} Strategy papers erroneously placed on the Clubs Queensland public website seem to indicate that clubs are deliberately and purposefully exaggerating the impact that the pre-commitment reforms will have on their services.{{cite web |url=http://www.news.com.au/national/clubs-australia-private-strategy-paper-calls-for-trailer-mounted-atms-to-circumvent-federal-governments-poker-machine-reforms/story-e6frfkvr-1226162190038 |title=Clubs Australia private strategy paper calls for trailer-mounted ATMs to circumvent Federal Government's poker machine reforms |publisher=News Ltd |accessdate=9 October 2011 |date=9 October 2011}} The same papers outlined some strategies that the clubs could use to exploit loopholes in the proposed reform. The [[National Rugby League]] (NRL) aligned themselves with the campaign in opposing the pre-commitment plans, as did some prominent [[Australian Football League]] (AFL) people. Commentators from the [[Nine Network]] gave planned political arguments without disclosure during commentary of a Semi-final NRL game, prompting the [[Australian Communications and Media Authority]] (ACMA) to investigate, stating "Channel Nine broadcast political material without adequately identifying it as such during the NRL first preliminary final". One of the accused commentators stated that the remarks were a "directive from up top that it be read by at least somebody". Investigations were predicted to take months.{{cite web|author=clubsnsw |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1CVxAlyGRdI |title=Channel 9 support campaign against MPC during NRL semi-final broadcast |publisher=YouTube |date=23 September 2011 |accessdate=19 November 2011}}{{cite web|last=Maiden |first=Samantha |url=http://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/news/andrew-wilkie-blows-the-whistle-on-channel-nine/story-e6freuy9-1226155203893 |title=Andrew Wilkie blows the whistle on Channel Nine: Daily Telegraph 2 October 2011 |work=The Daily Telegraph |location=Australia |date=2 October 2011 |accessdate=19 November 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://news.smh.com.au/breaking-news-national/media-watchdog-to-probe-nrl-commentators-20111004-1l6is.html |title=Media watchdog to probe NRL commentators |work=Sydney Morning Herald |date=4 October 2011 |accessdate=19 November 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2011-10-04/ch9-investigated-over-pokies-comments/3208422 |title=Channel Nine investigated over pokies comments: ABC 4 October 2011 |publisher=ABC |location=Australia |accessdate=19 November 2011}} [[Andrew Demetriou]], chief executive officer of the AFL, rejected suggestions that the AFL was joining Clubs Australia in their media campaign despite opposition to the plan by Collingwood president Eddie McGuire. Other high-profile club bosses including Jeff Kennett (Hawthorn) and David Smorgon (Bulldogs),{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2011-09-26/demetriou-rejects-afl-linked-to-pokie-campaign/2942900 |title=AFL boss rejects talk of pokie reform campaign: ABC 26 September 2011 |publisher=ABC |location=Australia |date=26 September 2011 |accessdate=19 November 2011}} and also stated "The fellow from Clubs Australia, I don't even know his name, but please, stop talking on our behalf, just shut up, that'd be a good help".{{cite web|url=http://www.smh.com.au/afl/afl-news/shut-up-afl-tells-pokies-campaigners-20110926-1kt63.html |title=Shut up, AFL tells pokies campaigners: SMH 26 September 2011 |work=Sydney Morning Herald |date=26 September 2011 |accessdate=19 November 2011}} Activist group [[GetUp!]] attempted to counter the anti-pre-commitment campaign by running political commercials during the NRL grand final{{cite web|url=http://www.smh.com.au/national/getup-to-air-pokies-ad-during-grand-final-20111002-1l3e7.html |title=GetUp to air pokies ad during grand final: SMH 2 October 2011 |work=Sydney Morning Herald |date=2 October 2011 |accessdate=19 November 2011}}{{cite web|author=getupaustralia |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lpF5uqPHrhA |title="Rob U Blind – Pokies", by GetUp |publisher=YouTube |accessdate=19 November 2011}} but all three major commercial television stations refused to air more of them.{{cite news|last=Willingham|first=Richard|title=Networks refuse to air anti-pokie ads|url=http://www.canberratimes.com.au/opinion/political-news/networks-refuse-to-air-antipokie-ads-20120515-1yp3y.html|accessdate=19 March 2013|newspaper=The Canberra Times|date=16 May 2012}}{{cite web|author=getupaustralia |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Z00v00L3I5Q |title="The Pokies People", by GetUp |publisher=YouTube |accessdate=19 March 2013}}{{cite web|title=Gambling With Lives|url=http://www.thepokiespeople.com/|work=The Pokies People|accessdate=19 March 2013}} ==Personal life== Wilkie married Kate Burton in 2004 and had two daughters. However, they separated in 2012 and divorced the following year, with Wilkie citing stress from the 2010–2013 hung parliament as the main cause of the breakdown.{{cite web|url=http://www.couriermail.com.au/news/queensland/independent-andrew-wilkie-says-he-lost-his-marriage-to-kate-burton-because-of-the-stress-of-the-hung-parliament/story-fnihsrf2-1226703136551 |title=Independent Andrew Wilkie says he lost his marriage to Kate Burton because of the stress of the hung parliament |publisher=couriermail |date= |accessdate=2014-06-12}} Wilkie was married to a fellow army officer, [[Simone Wilkie]] (née Burt), from 1991 to 2003.{{cite book |title=Who's Who in Australia 2013 |p=2405 |edition=XLIX |publisher=Crown Content |year=2013 |location=Melbourne |issn=0810-8226 |isbn=1 74095 190 5 |editor-first=Leanne |editor-last=Sullivan }} ==References== ===Notes=== {{Reflist|30em}} ===Sources=== * {{Cite book |first=Andrew |last=Wilkie |title=Axis of Deceit |publisher=[[Schwarz Publishing]] |location=Melbourne |year=2004 |isbn=0-9750769-2-2}} (''The story of the intelligence officer who risked all to tell the truth about [[Weapons of mass destruction|WMD]] and [[2003 invasion of Iraq|Iraq]]'': cover) ==External links== {{Commons category|Andrew Wilkie}} * {{Official website|http://www.andrewwilkie.org }} {{OpenAustralia}} {{s-start}} {{s-par|au}} {{s-bef|before=[[Duncan Kerr]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Division of Denison|Member for Denison]]|years=2010–present}} {{s-inc}} {{s-end}} {{Current House of Representatives crossbench}} {{Current Tasmania Representatives}} {{Laureates of the Sam Adams Award}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Wilkie, Andrew}} [[Category:1961 births]] [[Category:Australian Army officers]] Denison]] [[Category:People from Tamworth, New South Wales]] [[Category:Royal Military College, Duntroon graduates]] [[Category:21st-century Australian politicians]]
